entry.title: Docker and k8s basics
entry.content:
TL;DR: This article is about basics of Docker & K8s.

Docker

Use containers to build, share and run your appplications

Main concepts

  • Container: A container is a standard unit of software that packages up code and all its dependencies so the application runs quickly and reliably from one computing environment to another.

  • Image: A Docker container image is a lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries and settings.

âœ¨ images become containers when they run on Docker Engine.

Advantages

  • Standard: Docker created the industry standard for containers, so they could be portable anywhere.
  • Lightweight: Containers share the machineâ€™s OS system kernel and therefore do not require an OS per application, driving higher server efficiencies and reducing server and licensing costs.
  • Secure: Applications are safer in containers and Docker provides the strongest default isolation capabilities in the industry.

Kubernetes

Kubernetes, also known as K8s, is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

Features

  • Automated rollouts and rollbacks: k8s progressively rolls out changes and will monitor the application health. If something wrong, k8s will rollback automatically.

  • Service discovery and load balancing: Kubernetes gives Pods their own IP addresses and a single DNS name for a set of Pods, and can load-balance across them.

  • Storage orchestration: Automatically mount the storage system(local storage or public cloud provider).

  • Self-healing: Restarts containers that fail, replaces and reschedules containers when nodes die.

  • Secret and configuration management: Deploy and update secrets and application configuration without rebuilding your image and without exposing secrets in your stack configuration.

  • Automatic bin packing

    Automatically places containers based on their resource requirements and other constraints.

  • Batch execution
    In addition to services, Kubernetes can manage your batch and CI workloads, replacing containers that fail, if desired.

  • Horizontal scaling

    Scale your application up and down with a simple command, with a UI, or automatically based on CPU usage.

  • IPv4/IPv6 dual-stack

    Allocation of IPv4 and IPv6 addresses to Pods and Services.

  • Designed for extensibility

    Add features to your Kubernetes cluster without changing upstream source code.

Reference

  • What is container?

  • K8s

entry.title: Setup local kubernetes enviroment
entry.content:
Setup local kubernetes environment

This article is about setting up local k8s environment for testing and learning k8s

Some prerequisites

  • Homebrew
  • Docker

Install minikube

minikube is local Kubernetes, focusing on making it easy to learn and develop for Kubernetes.

  • Using homebrew to install minikube

Start minikube

Check if the minikube environment is created successfully

Other easy access online environments

  • killercoda

â€¦

Deployment

Create deployment.yaml

I strongly recommend you to use vscodeâ€™s k8s extension, it will help you to create the yaml file by providing some templates.

Apply the deployment

Check the deployment

Access the service

For this step, because we are using minikube, we need to use the minikube service command to access the service.

Delete the deployment

Reference

  • minikube docs

entry.title: What is Helm
entry.content:
How Helm works

What is Helm

  • Helm is a package manager for Kubernetes

What is Helm chart

  • Helm chart is a bundle of YAML files
  • We can create our own helm chart and push them to the helm repository
  • Also we can download and use existing chart in helm repository
  • Including database apps(MongoDB, MySQL), monitoring apps(Prometheus)â€¦

Commonly used command

Chart structure

What is Tiller

Tiller is a server-side helm in k8s clusters that helps install the package in the cluster.

But Tiller has too much power inside the k8s cluster, so it may have many security issues. In helm3, Tiller is deprecated.

Reference

  • Helm
  • TechWorld with Nana
